intro: Vasconcellea quercifolia, commonly known as the oak-leaf huito, is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae. It is native to tropical regions of Central and South America, where it typically grows in humid forests and along riverbanks. The plant is characterized by its large, palmate leaves that resemble the shape of an oak leaf, giving it its common name. It produces showy, yellowish-orange flowers that are clustered in panicles, and its fruit is a capsule containing numerous seeds. Vasconcellea quercifolia is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has traditional uses in local medicine.
